title: NORCO: Election centers on raising cash for projects
text:
BY PATRICK O’NEILL / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 2, 2015 3:54 p.m. NORCO: Election centers on raising cash for projects 1 of 8 More Seven candidates are running for the Norco City Council in the Nov. 3 election. COURTESY OF CITY OF NORCO Related article » NORCO CITY COUNCIL Seven candidates are running for three seats in the Nov. 3 election.
Robin Grundmeyer
Age: 40
Family: Two children
Occupation: Teaches agriculture and government at Norco High School
Education: Master's degree in Agriculture Science, Cal Poly Pomona; bachelor's degree in Agriculture Education, Colorado State University
Community activities: Member of the Norco Fair Committee, Day of the Cowboy Committee, volunteer with the Mounted Posse and Norco Horse Week.
Campaign phone/website: www.robingrundmeyerforcouncil.weebly.com
Jason Bemowski
Age: 35
Family: Two children
Occupation: Chino Police Department sergeant
Education: Bachelor's degree in Criminal Justice, California Coast University
Community activities: Volunteer with youth programs through the department and the Let It Be Foundation, which aids families of sick children.
Campaign phone/website: On Facebook at "Jason Bemowski for Norco City Council"
Lance Gregory
Age: 50
Family: One child
Occupation: Owner of Exact Color, a Norco printing company
Education: Associate's degree in the arts, Orange Coast College
Community activities: Member streets and trails commission, volunteer with the Norco Fair, Horse Week, Animal Rescue Team, and RURAL community action group.
Campaign phone/website: 714-856-2925, www.electlancegregory.webs.com
Berwin Hanna
Age: 72
Family: Three children
Occupation: Retired farrier
Education: Coursework in Agricultural Business, Sulross State College
Community activities: Eight years as a Norco city councilman, has been mayor twice, founding member of the Norco Horseman's Association and the Norco Animal Rescue Team.
Campaign phone/website: On Facebook at "Committee to Re-Elect Berwin Hanna"
Ted Hoffman
Age: 62
Family: One child
Occupation: Retired Riverside County sheriff's sergeant, operator of Ted Hoffman's Portable Arenas
Education: Associate's degree in Animal Science, Mt. San Jacinto College
Community activities: Member of the Norco Planning Commission, former streets and trails commissioner, founding member of Day of the Cowboy, was honored by the city for the past two years for more than 1,000 hours of volunteer time.
Campaign phone/website: 951-712-9582, on Facebook at "Committee to Elect Ted Hoffman to Norco City Council 2015"
Lisa Campbell
Age: 52
Occupation: Control center specialist with Rapid Response Monitoring
Education: Associate's degree in Liberal Arts, Golden West College; Bachelor's degree in Criminal Justice, Cal State Long Beach
Community activities: Member of the Norco Horse Week Committee, the Norco Fair Committee, historian for the Saddle Sore Riders.
Campaign phone/website: On Facebook at "Lisa Campbell for Council"
Herb Higgins
Age: 71
Occupation: Runs Higgins & Associates consulting, retired vice president of a contracting company
Education: Associate's degree in Administration of Justice, Chaffey College; Associates degree in Business Law, Cal State Bakersfield
Community activities: Twelve years as a Norco councilman, was mayor three times, member of planning commission, streets and trails commission and parks and recreation commission. Member of the Norco Horseman's Association, RURAL, Lions Club, Horse Week Committee and the Masonic Lodge.
Campaign phone/website: 909-815-5883, on Facebook at "Higgins for Norco City Council 2015"
Three of the five Norco City Council seats are up for grabs next month, and all seven Norco City Council candidates say increasing revenue for long-term city projects is a top priority.
Norco has struggled to gather money for capital improvements over the past several years, due at least in part to the recession and the end of redevelopment in 2011, said City Councilman Kevin Bash, who is not up for re-election until 2017.
The recent soft opening of Silverlakes Equestrian and Sports Park on Hamner Avenue has piqued the interest of developers, and the success of businesses moving into Norco will affect the city’s ability to complete long overdue projects such as replacing sewer lines and repairing horse trail fencing.
Incumbents Herb Higgins and Berwin Hanna are seeking new terms on Nov. 3. They’re joined by five other hopefuls: Jason Bemowski, Lisa Campbell, Ted Hoffman, Lance Gregory and Robin Grundmeyer. Each highlight their plans to meet the city’s infrastructure needs.
RAISING FUNDS Candidates approaches to achieving the goal vary.
Grundmeyer said the city should focus on attracting businesses along Hamner Avenue to bring in sales tax and other fees. A recreational runner, Grundmeyer said more events such as 5K runs would draw people into town and may keep them there overnight, raking in more tax revenue.
“We need to think outside the box about the types of events that can be hosted at our facilities,” Grundmeyer said. “The Brew N Cue Festival (a barbecue at Norco’s George Ingalls Equestrian Center) is a perfect example of how the right events can draw large groups of folks to our town.”
Many candidates said it’s important to strike while the iron is hot with respect to Silverlakes.
The city should capitalize by seeking businesses, restaurants and hotels, Campbell said.
“This means developing multiple vacant parcels within the city with point-of-sale businesses that will benefit the city via our portion of the sales tax revenue,” Campbell said.
Campbell, Gregory and Bemowski said one way to entice businesses is to make the city’s code enforcement department more efficient. Both recommend streamlining the permit process to reduce delays on new projects. Gregory said the city should hire another code enforcement officer to ensure the town doesn’t fall into disrepair.
“When there is a lack of enforcement this creates a ripple effect and can hurt home values and have a negative impact on the desire to be a destination spot,” Gregory said.
Bemowski also criticized the permitting process, saying the cumbersome format has stifled growth.
“Our permitting process is horrible and prevents business from easily growing and building,” said Bemowski, who pledged to make it “how it should be, with the city begging you to build and develop.”
RAISING REVENUE As Norco works to become a destination city, Higgins and Hoffman have proposed selling advertisements at local parks. For example, Higgins said, an arena at Ingalls Park could be named for a company and dozens of banners sold to regional advertisers.
Selling unused city land to developers was a quick, revenue-generating move favored by nearly all the candidates. Higgins took it one step further, proposing the partial sale of Neil Snipes Park along Hamner Avenue and the full sale of Parmenter Park on Reservoir Drive. The mayor said he’s met with developers and lawyers, trying to find the best fits for more than 130 acres of city land.
“It will give us more diversity, infrastructure money on development impact fees and an increase in tax dollars,” Higgins said.
Hoffman said Horsetown USA should push for businesses such as hotels to generate more taxes. Hoffman stressed the importance of protecting rural lifestyles as new development occurs.
“With two large properties (former Wyle Labs and Norco Egg Ranch) being looked at for future development, it is imperative that the council makes sure it protects the integrity of our city charter and zoning in its decision making,” Hoffman said.
Hanna, a current councilman, said he would push to market Ingalls Park and Silverlakes. Beyond that, Hanna said he’d look to the suggestions of a specially-formed city panel for a recommendation on how to build a rainy day fund for infrastructure.
